Contemporary Health Challenges and Biomedical Sciences 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS310
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programme:Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Contemporary Health Challenges and Biomedical Sciences
Short Title
Applied Biomedical Sciences
Module Code
BIOS310
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods

Maximum Places
150
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will cover a selection of contemporary diseases and conditions which challenge our local community and are of national/ international interest. These will be tackled from several Biomedical perspectives which will include but not be limited to Biochemistry, Epidemiology, Genetics, Microbiology, Physiology/ Pathophysiology. Students will select from a range of diseases/ conditions, which correspond to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen focus.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of important biomedical/ health challenges. They will learn how their skills and knowledge can be used to address research problems and bring about change to help mitigate and work towards alleviating these health challenges. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biomedical scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via lectures, workshops and tutorials. The lectures will put the spotlight on a variety of contemporaneous biomedical/ health challenges. The workshops allow students to focus on specific issues and develop the research skills necessary to address these challenges and suggest further initiatives/ areas for development. These workshops enhance existing skills and develop further abilities important for communication to broad audiences, analysis of multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary biomedical/ health problems from different biomedical science perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long-form written piece, detailing a healthcare challenge and potential solutions/ future directions for stakeholders.

Assessment of this module will be in the form of two assessments . The first will be an individual piece of work, which will be a science communication, based on an agreed health challenge. The submission format will be negotiated by each student from either recorded video, written report or a standalone poster. The second assessment will be a written consultancy report. This assessment involves analysis, conclusion and suggestion of future direction based on an authentic health related problem.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary healthcare challenges facing Liverpool, National and International communities
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of health challenges in biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and tackle these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role Biomedical Scientists have in addressing contemporary health challenges of the local, national and international communities.
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase, apply and enhance their knowledge of the contemporary health challenges from the perspective of the Biomedical Sciences. This will have a focus on the holistic understanding of a range of diseases/ conditions which are of special interest to the local Liverpool community and those further afield. It will allow students to apply and enhance their knowledge and skills to some of the health challenges facing biomedicine today. Students will apply their knowledge and scientific understanding to develop an evidence-based consultancy report suggesting actions which aim to alleviate these health challenges. Students will also engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. This module is assessed via two assessments, the consultancy report and a negotiated format science communications piece.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary Health challenges

Students will have a choice of health challenges to focus on which may include but are not limited to; heart diseases, diabetes, asthma, COPD, Cancer, emerging diseases, and public health.

The module begins with the introduction of Biomedical/ health challenges and proceeds with students working in groups within their chosen theme to develop a greater understanding of this challenge. Students will develop teamworking skills working together to research using a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor throughout the module. Emphasis will be placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards defining solutions. Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in Biomedical sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Student learning will be enhanced through engagement with departmental research seminars that cover a broad range of current research topics. This will enable the students to appreciate the diversity of biomedical research and how it can be applied to contemporary health challenges of importance to the local community and beyond. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, acquiring up-to-date information straight from a vibrant research community.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Research-connected teaching supported from the current research interests of University staff as experts in their field will feature as part of the Liverpool hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Lectures will cover topics relating to local, national and/ or international contemporary health challenges. Across the semester several discussion workshops/ tutorials will be led by academics on key and current issues or research-led themes relating to contemporary health challenges. Delivery is via three key lectures, six facilitated group learning sessions, 6 tutorials and 8 workshops. These are distributed throughout the semester.

• Plenary lectures: These sessions will lay the groundwork for the module, provide details on the assessment strategies and the intended module learning outcomes and provide information on contemporary health challenges.

• Group Working: Students will work in facilitated subsets, each of which tackles a different challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences. Discussion of these health challenges will promote deeper learning via application of knowledge developed throughout the degree so far. Groups will present short summaries to their peers, which will be followed by opportunities for questions and discussion. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles (i.e. Chairperson, notetaker, etc...) and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their recommendations/ solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biomedical sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen health challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Authentic assessment and digital fluency: There are two assessment components. Science communication, as a negotiated assessment via video blog/ written report/ poster is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – scientific communication, problem-solving, etc. The extended writing to produce a consultancy report requires students to lead their own enquiry to analyse, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge, geared towards recommendation for future direction. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative feedback will be provided throughout facilitated group work session and workshops, based on discussions during the sessions. Written formative feedback will be delivered by online platforms to aid in student learning.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

An individual science communication piece (40%) on an aspect of the health challenge their group has analysed. This could be a negotiated assessment with students choosing from the following options: recorded video, written report or standalone poster presentation. This assessment is both authentic and inclusive. Scientific communication is a benchmark employability skills and students can choose from a range of media to communicate with different audiences. Choice allows students to pursue their interests and develop or augment their chosen skill(s).

A concluding consultancy report (60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn, and suggested future directions are justified. This is an authentic assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Contemporary Health Challenges and Biomedical Sciences 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS310
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programme:Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Contemporary Health Challenges and Biomedical Sciences
Short Title
Applied Biomedical Sciences
Module Code
BIOS310
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods
Semester 2
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Terrence Gleave
Assigned To
Terrence Gleave
Life and Human Sciences Admin
Marketing
Quality Team
Status
 
Approved
Date of Approval
15 Jan 2024, 10:18
External Examiner(s)
Leda Mirbahai
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
150
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will cover a selection of contemporary diseases and conditions which challenge our local community and are of national/ international interest. These will be tackled from several Biomedical perspectives which will include but not be limited to Biochemistry, Epidemiology, Genetics, Microbiology, Physiology/ Pathophysiology. Students will select from a range of diseases/ conditions, which correspond to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen focus.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of important biomedical/ health challenges. They will learn how their skills and knowledge can be used to address research problems and bring about change to help mitigate and work towards alleviating these health challenges. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biomedical scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via lectures, workshops and tutorials. The lectures will put the spotlight on a variety of contemporaneous biomedical/ health challenges. The workshops allow students to focus on specific issues and develop the research skills necessary to address these challenges and suggest further initiatives/ areas for development. These workshops enhance existing skills and develop further abilities important for communication to broad audiences, analysis of multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary biomedical/ health problems from different biomedical science perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long-form written piece, detailing a healthcare challenge and potential solutions/ future directions for stakeholders.

Assessment of this module will be in the form of two assessments . The first will be an individual piece of work, which will be a science communication, based on an agreed health challenge. The submission format will be negotiated by each student from either recorded video, written report or a standalone poster. The second assessment will be a written consultancy report. This assessment involves analysis, conclusion and suggestion of future direction based on an authentic health related problem.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary healthcare challenges facing Liverpool, National and International communities
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of health challenges in biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and tackle these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role Biomedical Scientists have in addressing contemporary health challenges of the local, national and international communities.
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase, apply and enhance their knowledge of the contemporary health challenges from the perspective of the Biomedical Sciences. This will have a focus on the holistic understanding of a range of diseases/ conditions which are of special interest to the local Liverpool community and those further afield. It will allow students to apply and enhance their knowledge and skills to some of the health challenges facing biomedicine today. Students will apply their knowledge and scientific understanding to develop an evidence-based consultancy report suggesting actions which aim to alleviate these health challenges. Students will also engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. This module is assessed via two assessments, the consultancy report and a negotiated format science communications piece.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary Health challenges

Students will have a choice of health challenges to focus on which may include but are not limited to; heart diseases, diabetes, asthma, COPD, Cancer, emerging diseases, and public health.

The module begins with the introduction of Biomedical/ health challenges and proceeds with students working in groups within their chosen theme to develop a greater understanding of this challenge. Students will develop teamworking skills working together to research using a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor throughout the module. Emphasis will be placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards defining solutions. Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in Biomedical sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Student learning will be enhanced through engagement with departmental research seminars that cover a broad range of current research topics. This will enable the students to appreciate the diversity of biomedical research and how it can be applied to contemporary health challenges of importance to the local community and beyond. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, acquiring up-to-date information straight from a vibrant research community.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Research-connected teaching supported from the current research interests of University staff as experts in their field will feature as part of the Liverpool hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Lectures will cover topics relating to local, national and/ or international contemporary health challenges. Across the semester several discussion workshops/ tutorials will be led by academics on key and current issues or research-led themes relating to contemporary health challenges. Delivery is via three key lectures, six facilitated group learning sessions, 6 tutorials and 8 workshops. These are distributed throughout the semester.

• Plenary lectures: These sessions will lay the groundwork for the module, provide details on the assessment strategies and the intended module learning outcomes and provide information on contemporary health challenges.

• Group Working: Students will work in facilitated subsets, each of which tackles a different challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences. Discussion of these health challenges will promote deeper learning via application of knowledge developed throughout the degree so far. Groups will present short summaries to their peers, which will be followed by opportunities for questions and discussion. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles (i.e. Chairperson, notetaker, etc...) and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their recommendations/ solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biomedical sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen health challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Authentic assessment and digital fluency: There are two assessment components. Science communication, as a negotiated assessment via video blog/ written report/ poster is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – scientific communication, problem-solving, etc. The extended writing to produce a consultancy report requires students to lead their own enquiry to analyse, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge, geared towards recommendation for future direction. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative feedback will be provided throughout facilitated group work session and workshops, based on discussions during the sessions. Written formative feedback will be delivered by online platforms to aid in student learning.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

An individual science communication piece (40%) on an aspect of the health challenge their group has analysed. This could be a negotiated assessment with students choosing from the following options: recorded video, written report or standalone poster presentation. This assessment is both authentic and inclusive. Scientific communication is a benchmark employability skills and students can choose from a range of media to communicate with different audiences. Choice allows students to pursue their interests and develop or augment their chosen skill(s).

A concluding consultancy report (60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn, and suggested future directions are justified. This is an authentic assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin

Contemporary Health Challenges and Biomedical Sciences 2026-27

Blurb
Overview
This module will cover a selection of contemporary diseases and conditions which challenge our local community and are of national/ international interest. These will be tackled from several Biomedical perspectives which will include but not be limited to Biochemistry, Epidemiology, Genetics, Microbiology, Physiology/ Pathophysiology. Students will select from a range of diseases/ conditions, which correspond to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen focus.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of important biomedical/ health challenges. They will learn how their skills and knowledge can be used to address research problems and bring about change to help mitigate and work towards alleviating these health challenges. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biomedical scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via lectures, workshops and tutorials. The lectures will put the spotlight on a variety of contemporaneous biomedical/ health challenges. The workshops allow students to focus on specific issues and develop the research skills necessary to address these challenges and suggest further initiatives/ areas for development. These workshops enhance existing skills and develop further abilities important for communication to broad audiences, analysis of multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary biomedical/ health problems from different biomedical science perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long-form written piece, detailing a healthcare challenge and potential solutions/ future directions for stakeholders.

Assessment of this module will be in the form of two assessments . The first will be an individual piece of work, which will be a science communication, based on an agreed health challenge. The submission format will be negotiated by each student from either recorded video, written report or a standalone poster. The second assessment will be a written consultancy report. This assessment involves analysis, conclusion and suggestion of future direction based on an authentic health related problem.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary healthcare challenges facing Liverpool, National and International communities
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of health challenges in biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and tackle these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role Biomedical Scientists have in addressing contemporary health challenges of the local, national and international communities.
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module provides students with the opportunity to showcase, apply and enhance their knowledge of the contemporary health challenges from the perspective of the Biomedical Sciences. This will have a focus on the holistic understanding of a range of diseases/ conditions which are of special interest to the local Liverpool community and those further afield. It will allow students to apply and enhance their knowledge and skills to some of the health challenges facing biomedicine today. Students will apply their knowledge and scientific understanding to develop an evidence-based consultancy report suggesting actions which aim to alleviate these health challenges. Students will also engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool. This module is assessed via two assessments, the consultancy report and a negotiated format science communications piece.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary Health challenges

Students will have a choice of health challenges to focus on which may include but are not limited to; heart diseases, diabetes, asthma, COPD, Cancer, emerging diseases, and public health.

The module begins with the introduction of Biomedical/ health challenges and proceeds with students working in groups within their chosen theme to develop a greater understanding of this challenge. Students will develop teamworking skills working together to research using a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor throughout the module. Emphasis will be placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards defining solutions. Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in Biomedical sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Student learning will be enhanced through engagement with departmental research seminars that cover a broad range of current research topics. This will enable the students to appreciate the diversity of biomedical research and how it can be applied to contemporary health challenges of importance to the local community and beyond. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, acquiring up-to-date information straight from a vibrant research community.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Research-connected teaching supported from the current research interests of University staff as experts in their field will feature as part of the Liverpool hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Lectures will cover topics relating to local, national and/ or international contemporary health challenges. Across the semester several discussion workshops/ tutorials will be led by academics on key and current issues or research-led themes relating to contemporary health challenges. Delivery is via three key lectures, six facilitated group learning sessions, 6 tutorials and 8 workshops. These are distributed throughout the semester.

• Plenary lectures: These sessions will lay the groundwork for the module, provide details on the assessment strategies and the intended module learning outcomes and provide information on contemporary health challenges.

• Group Working: Students will work in facilitated subsets, each of which tackles a different challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences. Discussion of these health challenges will promote deeper learning via application of knowledge developed throughout the degree so far. Groups will present short summaries to their peers, which will be followed by opportunities for questions and discussion. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles (i.e. Chairperson, notetaker, etc...) and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their recommendations/ solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biomedical sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen health challenge in contemporary biomedical sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Authentic assessment and digital fluency: There are two assessment components. Science communication, as a negotiated assessment via video blog/ written report/ poster is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – scientific communication, problem-solving, etc. The extended writing to produce a consultancy report requires students to lead their own enquiry to analyse, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge, geared towards recommendation for future direction. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative feedback will be provided throughout facilitated group work session and workshops, based on discussions during the sessions. Written formative feedback will be delivered by online platforms to aid in student learning.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

An individual science communication piece (40%) on an aspect of the health challenge their group has analysed. This could be a negotiated assessment with students choosing from the following options: recorded video, written report or standalone poster presentation. This assessment is both authentic and inclusive. Scientific communication is a benchmark employability skills and students can choose from a range of media to communicate with different audiences. Choice allows students to pursue their interests and develop or augment their chosen skill(s).

A concluding consultancy report (60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn, and suggested future directions are justified. This is an authentic assessment.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate some of the major health challenges facing the local, national and international communities and a biomedical scientist’s role in mitigating/ seeking a solution, appreciating the bigger picture.
 LO2 Access and critically evaluate scientific and non-scientific information pertinent to contemporary health challenges.
 LO3 Conceptualise, develop and deliver a consultancy report on a health challenge from the perspective of a biomedical scientist.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 To develop high-level analytical skills and apply them to a complex problem to generate recommendations and possible solutions.
 S2 To communicate clearly using a range of media to a variety of audiences.
 S3 To develop professional teamwork skills as related to solving complex, multi-faceted problems.
 S4 Global citizenship
